definition_en: To mention a topic or start a discussion about it.

examples.sentence: I'd like to bring up the issue of budget cuts at the next meeting.
He brought up an interesting point about our marketing strategy.
This topic has been brought up several times already.
Don't bring up the merger unless they ask about it.

definition_en: To cancel an event or agreement.

examples.sentence: They had to call off the meeting because the CEO was ill.
The strike was called off after the management agreed to the terms.
If the weather is bad, we will call off the outdoor team-building event.
Calling off the deal now would be a huge mistake.

definition_en: To perform or complete a task or instruction.

examples.sentence: We need to carry out a thorough market analysis.
The team carried out the project ahead of schedule.
Instructions must be carried out precisely.
Who will be carrying out the inspection?

definition_en: To think of or produce an idea, plan, or solution.

examples.sentence: She came up with a brilliant solution to the logistics problem.
We need to come up with a better offer to win the client.
Have you come up with any ideas for the new campaign?
Coming up with new concepts is part of his job description.

definition_en: To reduce the amount or quantity of something, usually spending.

examples.sentence: The company had to cut back on expenses due to the recession.
We are planning to cut back our advertising budget.
Cutting back staff is always a difficult decision.
If we don't cut back, we will exceed our monthly limit.

definition_en: To handle a problem, person, or task; to manage.

examples.sentence: I deal with customer complaints on a daily basis.
How did you deal with the difficult client yesterday?
This issue needs to be deals with immediately.
Dealing with strict deadlines can be stressful.

definition_en: To prepare a document or plan formally.

examples.sentence: Our lawyers will draw up the contract by Friday.
They drew up a list of potential investors.
Once the agreement is drawn up, we can sign it.
She is busy drawing up the annual report.

definition_en: To fail to happen or be completed (of plans or arrangements).

examples.sentence: The deal fell through at the last minute.
We were afraid the project might fall through due to lack of funding.
If the financing falls through, we have a backup plan.
It's disappointing when months of negotiation fall through.

definition_en: To understand or solve a problem; to calculate.

examples.sentence: We need to figure out why sales dropped last month.
Review the data and figure out the total cost.
Have you figured out how to use the new software?
I can't figure him out; he never shares his opinion.

definition_en: To complete a form OR to substitute for someone.

examples.sentence: Please fill in this application form.
I will fill in for Sarah while she is on leave.
Can you fill me in on what happened at the meeting?
All fields must be filled in correctly.

definition_en: To pursue further action or communication on a matter.

examples.sentence: I'll follow up with an email summarising our discussion.
Did you follow up on the leads I sent you?
A follow-up meeting is scheduled for next week.
It is important to follow up promptly after networking events.

definition_en: To successfully communicate an idea or message.

examples.sentence: He struggled to get his point across during the debate.
We need to get the message across that safety comes first.
The presentation really got the value proposition across.
How can we best get this concept across to the team?

definition_en: To reply to someone or contact them again later.

examples.sentence: I'll get back to you with the figures by tomorrow.
She promised to get back to the client regarding the complaint.
Sorry for not getting back to you sooner.
Has he got back to you about the proposal yet?

definition_en: To surrender or agree to something you initially opposed.

examples.sentence: We couldn't give in to their unreasonable demands.
After hours of debate, the management finally gave in.
Don't give in too easily on the price during the negotiation.
Giving in now would set a bad precedent.

definition_en: To review or check something carefully.

examples.sentence: Let's go over the agenda before we start.
We went over the report line by line.
I want to go over the main points again.
Have you gone over the contract details?

definition_en: To pass responsibility or control to someone else.

examples.sentence: The manager will hand over his duties next month.
Please ensure a smooth handover of all files.
She handed over the project to her successor.
We are in the process of handing over the department.

definition_en: To delay action or decision.

examples.sentence: We should hold off on hiring new staff until Q3.
They held off signing the deal awaiting better terms.
Can we hold off the launch for another week?
Holding off now might cost us market share.

definition_en: To resolve small problems or details.

examples.sentence: We still need to iron out a few details in the contract.
The technical issues were ironed out before release.
Let's meet to iron out our differences.
Ironing out these bugs took longer than expected.

definition_en: To write something quickly.

examples.sentence: I'll just jot down your phone number.
Did you jot down the key points from the speech?
Let me grab a pen to jot this down.
She is always jotting down ideas in her notebook.

definition_en: To start an event or project.

examples.sentence: We will kick off the project with a team meeting.
The conference kicks off at 9 AM tomorrow.
To kick things off, I'd like to introduce our guest.
The campaign kicked off last week.

definition_en: To dismiss employees, usually for economic reasons.

examples.sentence: The company laid off 100 workers due to budget cuts.
They are planning to lay off staff next month.
Being laid off can be a difficult experience.
We hope to avoid laying anyone off.

definition_en: To explain or present a plan clearly.

examples.sentence: He laid out the strategy for the next quarter.
I will lay out the options clearly in my report.
The document lays out the terms of the agreement.
Can you lay out exactly how this will work?

definition_en: To investigate or examine a matter.

examples.sentence: I will look into the discrepancy in the accounts.
We are looking into possible locations for a new office.
This matter needs to be looked into immediately.
Have you looked into the customer's complaint yet?

definition_en: To write a check or document to a specific person.

examples.sentence: Who should I make the check out to?
Please make out the invoice to the company name.
He made out a receipt for the cash payment.
The document was made out incorrectly.

definition_en: To give a message or information to someone else.

examples.sentence: Could you pass on this message to Mr. Smith?
I will pass on your feedback to the development team.
She passed on the news as soon as she heard it.
Please ensure these instructions are passed on to all staff.

definition_en: To yield good results; to succeed.

examples.sentence: All our hard work finally paid off.
The investment is starting to pay off.
We hope this strategy pays off in the long run.
It paid off to prepare thoroughly for the interview.

definition_en: To learn a new skill naturally; to improve.

examples.sentence: She picked up the new software very quickly.
Sales have picked up significantly this quarter.
I managed to pick up some useful industry jargon.
Business usually picks up in the spring.

definition_en: To draw attention to something.

examples.sentence: I'd like to point out a potential risk.
She pointed out that the deadline is tomorrow.
Thank you for pointing out that error.
As John pointed out earlier, we are over budget.

definition_en: To withdraw from an agreement or situation.

examples.sentence: The investor pulled out of the deal.
They are threatening to pull out if we don't agree.
Pulling out now would damage our reputation.
We can't pull out once the contract is signed.

definition_en: To propose an idea or candidate.

examples.sentence: I'd like to put forward a new proposal.
Several candidates were put forward for the role.
She put forward a compelling argument.
He has put himself forward for the committee.

definition_en: To delay or postpone.

examples.sentence: We had to put off the meeting until next week.
Never put off until tomorrow what you can do today.
They keep putting off the decision.
The launch was put off due to technical issues.

definition_en: To contact someone for help or cooperation.

examples.sentence: Feel free to reach out if you have questions.
I reached out to several potential partners.
We are reaching out to new markets.
Thank you for reaching out to us.

definition_en: To eliminate a possibility.

examples.sentence: We can't rule out the possibility of a merger.
This option has been ruled out.
Ruling out that supplier would be a mistake.
Did they rule out price as a factor?

definition_en: To explain something to someone for approval/feedback.

examples.sentence: Can I run this idea by you?
I need to run these changes by the manager.
He ran the proposal by the legal team.
Please run it by me before sending.

definition_en: To encounter problems or people unexpectedly.

examples.sentence: We ran into some technical difficulties.
If you run into any issues, let me know.
I ran into an old colleague at the conference.
Running into unexpected costs is common.

definition_en: To have no more of something left.

examples.sentence: We are running out of time for this meeting.
The printer has run out of paper.
We ran out of budget halfway through the project.
Don't accept the offer until we run out of options.

definition_en: To check, practise, or rehearse something quickly.

examples.sentence: Let's run through the presentation one more time.
Can we run through the agenda quickly?
I'll run through the main points.
Running through the checklist is mandatory.

definition_en: To arrange or establish something.

examples.sentence: I'll set up a meeting for next Tuesday.
They set up a subsidiary in Germany.
The equipment needs to be set up properly.
Setting up a business requires capital.

definition_en: To give official approval.

examples.sentence: The CEO needs to sign off on this budget.
Has the project been signed off yet?
We are waiting for sign-off from the legal department.
I'm signing off for the day.

definition_en: To resolve a problem or organize something.

examples.sentence: We need to sort out the logistics immediately.
Everything has been sorted out.
Can you help me sort out these files?
Sorting out customer queries is his main duty.

definition_en: To speak louder OR to express an opinion.

examples.sentence: Could you speak up a bit? I can't hear you.
You should speak up if you disagree with the plan.
She wasn't afraid to speak up against the decision.
Speaking up in large meetings takes confidence.

definition_en: To represent or mean (acronyms) OR to tolerate.

examples.sentence: What does CEO stand for?
Our company stands for integrity and quality.
We will not stand for harassment in the workplace.
I don't know what this acronym stands for.

definition_en: To resign from a position.

examples.sentence: The director decided to step down last week.
He is stepping down as chairman.
She faced pressure to step down.
After 20 years, stepping down was emotional.

definition_en: To accept responsibility OR hire staff.

examples.sentence: I can't take on any more work right now.
We are taking on five new graduates.
She took on the challenge of leading the new team.
Taking on big clients requires more resources.

definition_en: To take control of something.

examples.sentence: Our company was taken over by a large competitor.
She will take over as manager next month.
Can you take over this task for me?
The takeover bid was successful.

definition_en: To discuss a problem or plan.

examples.sentence: We need to talk over the proposal before deciding.
They talked it over for hours.
Let's talk this over lunch.
Talking things over helps clarify the situation.

definition_en: To consider something carefully.

examples.sentence: I need some time to think over your offer.
He promised to think it over.
After thinking it over, I decided to accept.
Have you thought over the consequences?

definition_en: To reject an offer or request.

examples.sentence: He turned down the job offer.
Our proposal was turned down by the board.
Why did they turn down our application?
Turning down a client is sometimes necessary.

definition_en: To compare pros and cons.

examples.sentence: We need to weigh up the benefits and risks.
She weighed up her options before quitting.
After weighing everything up, we chose Plan B.
It's difficult to weigh up intangible assets.

definition_en: To finish a meeting or task.

examples.sentence: Let's wrap up this meeting.
We aim to wrap up the project by Friday.
Just to wrap up, I'd like to thank everyone.
The negotiation was wrapped up quickly.

definition_en: To explain the reason for something or form a part of a total.

examples.sentence: How do you account for the loss in revenue?
Sales in Asia account for 30% of our profit.
They couldn't account for the missing files.
There are several factors to account for.

definition_en: To support someone or make a copy of data.

examples.sentence: Don't forget to back up your files daily.
My manager backed me up in the meeting.
We need evidence to back up these claims.
The traffic was backed up for miles.

definition_en: To rescue someone or something from financial difficulty.

examples.sentence: The government bailed out the banks.
He bailed me out when I was short of cash.
We cannot keep bailing out failing departments.
A bailout package was approved.

definition_en: To rely on or count on something happening.

examples.sentence: We are banking on a sales increase this quarter.
Don't bank on the loan being approved.
I wouldn't bank on it.
They banked on their competitor failing.

definition_en: To expand into new areas of business.

examples.sentence: The company decided to branch out into software.
Branching out is risky but necessary.
We need to branch out to survive.
They have branched out significantly since 2020.

definition_en: To enter a new market or industry successfully.

examples.sentence: It is difficult to break into the Chinese market.
They broke into the luxury sector last year.
We are trying to break into a new niche.
Breaking into this industry requires connections.

definition_en: To reduce costs or prices.

examples.sentence: We aim to bring down production costs.
Competition has brought down prices.
Can you bring down the final offer?
The scandal brought down the CEO.

definition_en: To become exhausted from overwork.

examples.sentence: If you keep working like this, you will burn out.
Employee burnout is a serious issue.
She burned out after five years in trading.
We need to prevent staff from burning out.

definition_en: To purchase someone's share of a business.

examples.sentence: He wants to buy out his partner.
The company was bought out by a private equity firm.
They offered a buyout package to older employees.
Buying out the competition is their strategy.

definition_en: To profit from a situation.
translation_pl: zarobić na czymś, skorzystać z okazji

examples.sentence: The company cashed in on the sudden demand.
We should cash in on our brand popularity.
Investors are cashing in on rising tech stocks.
Don't miss the chance to cash in.

definition_en: To report one's arrival OR contact someone for an update.
translation_pl: zameldować się, odezwać się (sprawdzić co słychać)

examples.sentence: I need to check in at the hotel by 6 PM.
I'm just checking in to see how the project is going.
Please check in with me when you arrive.
Have you checked in for your flight?

definition_en: To leave a hotel OR investigate something.

examples.sentence: We need to check out by 11 AM.
You should check out their new website.
I'll check out the competition's pricing.
Check it out!

definition_en: To stop operating (a business) permanently.

examples.sentence: Many small shops closed down during the pandemic.
They are forced to close down the branch.
The factory was closed down for safety violations.
Closing down sale starts tomorrow.

definition_en: To find by chance OR to seem/appear to others.

examples.sentence: I came across this resume yesterday.
He comes across as very confident.
How did I come across in the interview?
Such opportunities don't come across often.

definition_en: To outsource work to another company.

examples.sentence: We decided to contract out the cleaning services.
Manufacturing is often contracted out to Asia.
Contracting out this project will save time.
They contract out most of their IT work.

definition_en: To rely on someone or something.

examples.sentence: You can count on me to finish the report.
We are counting on this deal to go through.
I knew I could count on his support.
Don't count on it.

definition_en: To use a small amount of savings or resources.

examples.sentence: We had to dip into our reserves.
avoid dipping into the pension fund.
Sales are down, so we are dipping into savings.
He dipped into his own pocket to pay for it.

definition_en: To remove or abolish something.

examples.sentence: We should do away with unnecessary paperwork.
They did away with the old bonus system.
The department was not done away with completely.
Doing away with these rules will boost morale.

definition_en: To continue for too long.

examples.sentence: The meeting dragged on for three hours.
Don't let the negotiations drag on.
This project has dragged on long enough.
If the lawsuit drags on, costs will rise.

definition_en: To use experience or resources.

examples.sentence: I will draw on my experience in marketing.
The company draws on a global network of experts.
We can draw on the reserve fund if needed.
He drew on his savings to start the business.

definition_en: To visit unexpectedly or briefly.

examples.sentence: Feel free to drop in anytime.
I'll drop in on the client while I'm in town.
She dropped in to say hello.
Sales dropped in Q3.

definition_en: To deliver someone/something OR to decrease.

examples.sentence: Can you drop off these documents at HQ?
Demand dropped off after Christmas.
I need to drop off a parcel.
Attendance has dropped off recently.

definition_en: To eventually reach a state or place.

examples.sentence: We ended up spending more than planned.
If we don't act, we'll end up bankrupt.
She ended up as the CEO.
I don't want to end up in a legal battle.

definition_en: To accept and deal with a difficult situation.

examples.sentence: We must face up to the reality of the market.
He finally faced up to his responsibilities.
It's time to face up to the facts.
Companies need to face up to climate change.

definition_en: To fail to keep up with schedule or competitors.
translation_pl: zostać w tyle (z robotą, za konkurencją)

examples.sentence: We are falling behind schedule.
Don't fall behind on your payments.
The company fell behind its competitors.
I fell behind with my emails while on holiday.

definition_en: To defend against an attack or hostile takeover.

examples.sentence: They fought off a hostile takeover bid.
We are fighting off competition from low-cost rivals.
Fighting off these allegations is our priority.
It was hard to fight off the critics.

definition_en: To complete a form (similar to fill in).

examples.sentence: Please fill out this survey.
Required fields must be filled out.
He filled out an application for the grant.
Identifying and filling out tax forms is complex.

definition_en: To give attention to something.

examples.sentence: We need to focus on our core business.
She is focusing on improving customer service.
The report focuses on sustainability.
Let's keep the focus on sales.

definition_en: To progress or succeed in your career.

examples.sentence: Networking helps you get ahead.
She worked hard to get ahead of her colleagues.
Getting ahead in this industry is tough.
He got ahead by taking risks.

definition_en: To have a good relationship with someone.

examples.sentence: It's important to get along with your team.
Do you get along with your boss?
They didn't get along with each other.
Getting along with clients is crucial.

definition_en: To manage/survive with limited resources.

examples.sentence: The startup is just getting by.
We can get by with a smaller team for now.
It's hard to get by on this budget.
They got by without external funding.

definition_en: To start doing something seriously.

examples.sentence: Let's get down to business.
It's time to get down to work.
After the break, we got down to the details.
Getting down to the nitty-gritty.

definition_en: To proceed with a plan.
translation_pl: ruszyć z czymś, dostać zielone światło

examples.sentence: We got the green light to go ahead.
Please go ahead with the presentation.
The project is going ahead as planned.
Before going ahead, check the costs.

definition_en: To go bankrupt.

examples.sentence: Many businesses went under during the recession.
We are afraid the supplier might go under.
Seeing a competitor go under is sobering.
The firm is in danger of going under.

definition_en: To submit an assignment or resignation.

examples.sentence: She handed in her resignation yesterday.
Please hand in your reports by Friday.
He forgot to hand in the expense claim.
Handing in notice is a formal process.

definition_en: To lead or be in charge of a department/project.

examples.sentence: Who will head up the new division?
She was chosen to head up the project.
He has been heading up sales for 5 years.
Heading up a team requires patience.

definition_en: To delay someone or something.

examples.sentence: We were held up by traffic.
What is holding up the project?
Don't let minor details hold up the process.
The hold-up cost us money.

definition_en: To move at the same speed as; to stay informed.

examples.sentence: It's hard to keep up with technology changes.
We must keep up with our competitors.
She reads industry news to keep up.
Keeping up with emails is a daily struggle.

definition_en: To start working hard.
translation_pl: przyłożyć się do pracy, wziąć się do roboty

examples.sentence: It's time to knuckle down and finish this.
They knuckled down after the break.
We need to knuckle down to meet the target.
If you knuckle down, you'll succeed.

definition_en: To be honest with someone.

examples.sentence: I'll level with you; the situation is bad.
He didn't level with us about the risks.
Please level with me.
Leveling with employees builds trust.

definition_en: To meet a standard or expectation.

examples.sentence: The new product didn't measure up to expectations.
Does he measure up to the job requirements?
It's hard to measure up to their standards.
Measuring up is not always easy.

definition_en: To write something to remember it.

examples.sentence: Please note down the reference number.
I noted down the main points.
She is noting down your suggestions.
Make sure to note it down.

definition_en: To choose not to participate.

examples.sentence: You can opt out of the pension scheme.
Many customers opted out of the email list.
An opt-out clause is included.
Choosing to opt out has consequences.

definition_en: To issue or introduce gradually.

examples.sentence: We will phase in the new software over 3 months.
The changes are being phased in.
Phasing in the rules gently is better.
They phased in the price hike.

definition_en: To remove or stop using gradually.

examples.sentence: We are phasing out the old model.
Paper checks are being phased out.
The government plans to phase out the subsidy.
A complete phase-out by 2030.

definition_en: To prepare for the future.

examples.sentence: We need to plan ahead to avoid delays.
He is good at planning ahead.
If you don't plan ahead, you fail.
Planning ahead is essential in this market.

definition_en: To continue with determination.

examples.sentence: They pressed ahead with the launch despite the risks.
We must press ahead with reform.
Are we pressing ahead or pausing?
Pressing ahead regardless can be dangerous.

definition_en: To return with information.

examples.sentence: Please report back to me by noon.
She reported back on the client meeting.
I'm waiting for the team to report back.
Reporting back regularly ensures alignment.

definition_en: To increase the size or scale of operations.

examples.sentence: We want to scale up production.
The startup is scaling up rapidly.
Scaling up requires more capital.
They scaled up their marketing efforts.

definition_en: To sell assets, usually because of financial need.

examples.sentence: The company sold off its real estate assets.
They are selling off the non-core divisions.
A massive sell-off occurred in the market.
Selling off inventory at a discount.

definition_en: To ask many people the same question.

examples.sentence: I'll ask around to see if anyone knows a good developer.
She asked around the office but nobody knew.
Asking around is the best way to find recommendations.
Did you ask around before deciding?

definition_en: To withdraw from an agreement/commitment.

examples.sentence: They backed out of the deal at the last minute.
It's too late to back out now.
He promised not to back out.
Backing out would be unprofessional.

definition_en: To explode OR to become suddenly angry.

examples.sentence: My boss blew up when he saw the mistake.
The scandal could blow up in our faces.
Don't blow up over small things.
The project blew up (failed drastically).

definition_en: To stop working (machine) OR to analyze in detail.
translation_pl: zepsuć się, rozłożyć na czynniki pierwsze

examples.sentence: The server broke down yesterday.
Can you break down the budget for me?
Negotiations broke down after hours.
Let's break this problem down into parts.

definition_en: To return a phone call.

examples.sentence: I will call you back in 5 minutes.
Has he called back yet?
Please ask him to call me back.
Calling back customers promptly is vital.

definition_en: To request the presence of a specialist/help.

examples.sentence: We had to call in a consultant.
She called in sick today.
They called in the loans.
Calling in favours is sometimes necessary.

definition_en: To reach the same standard/level OR exchange news.

examples.sentence: I have a lot of work to catch up on.
Let's grab a coffee and catch up.
Go ahead, I'll catch up with you.
We need to catch up to our competitors.

definition_en: To monitor someone or verify their condition.

examples.sentence: My boss is always checking up on me.
I need to check up on the new intern.
Checking up on progress is part of the job.
Did you check up on that client?

definition_en: To tidy OR to clarify a misunderstanding.

examples.sentence: We hope to clear up the confusion soon.
Can you clear up this mess on your desk?
The weather cleared up later.
Let's clear up any doubts before signing.

definition_en: To make progress OR accompany someone.

examples.sentence: How is the project coming along?
Do you want to come along to the lunch?
The report is coming along nicely.
A better opportunity might come along.

definition_en: To return.

examples.sentence: When will you come back from leave?
We can come back to this topic later.
The problem keep coming back.
Don't come back without a signed contract.

definition_en: To be published/released OR result.

examples.sentence: The new report comes out next week.
It came out that he was lying.
How did the figures come out?
Everything came out fine in the end.

definition_en: To visit someone's place OR to affect someone.

examples.sentence: Why don't you come over to my office?
I don't know what came over me.
He came over from the London branch.
Can you come over and help me?

definition_en: To include someone.

examples.sentence: If you're ordering lunch, count me in.
Did you count John in for the meeting?
Count me in for the project.
You can count us in.

definition_en: To disconnect (phone/service) OR isolate.

examples.sentence: We were cut off in the middle of the call.
The supplier cut off our credit.
Don't cut me off while I'm speaking.
They felt cut off from the main office.

definition_en: To manage without something.

examples.sentence: We'll have to do without extra staff.
I can't do without my laptop.
You'll just have to do without.
Doing without luxury items saves money.

definition_en: To wear formal or fancy clothes.

examples.sentence: We need to dress up for the gala.
You don't have to dress up; it's casual.
He likes dressing up for work.
Is it a dress-up party?

definition_en: To move back or fall behind.

examples.sentence: He dropped back to help his colleague.
Sales dropped back to 2019 levels.
Don't drop back now.
The stock dropped back after the rally.

definition_en: To eat in a restaurant.

examples.sentence: We eat out quite often with clients.
Let's eat out tonight.
Eating out is expensive in London.
They ate out to celebrate the deal.

definition_en: To break into pieces or fail completely.

examples.sentence: The whole plan fell apart.
This old printer is falling apart.
The team spirit is falling apart.
Don't let the deal fall apart.

definition_en: To make something full.

examples.sentence: I need to fill up the car with petrol.
The room filled up quickly.
My schedule is filling up.
Fill it up, please.

definition_en: To discover information.

examples.sentence: I need to find out the price.
We found out that he quit.
Can you find out who is in charge?
Finding out the truth is important.

definition_en: To escape or go on holiday.

examples.sentence: I need to get away for a few days.
We got away to the coast for the weekend.
There was no getting away from the noise.
Did the thief get away?

definition_en: To return.

examples.sentence: When do you get back from New York?
I just got back from lunch.
We need to get back to basics.
Getting back late makes me tired.

definition_en: To arrive (train/flight) OR enter (car/building).

examples.sentence: What time does your flight get in?
I didn't get in until midnight.
Get in the car!
We need to get a specialist in.

definition_en: To leave a bus/train/etc OR finish work.

examples.sentence: I usually get off work at 5 PM.
We need to get off at the next station.
He got off the phone quickly.
Getting off to a good start is important.

definition_en: To board a vehicle OR make progress.

examples.sentence: Please get on the bus quickly.
How are you getting on with the task?
He is getting on well in his new job.
Let's get on with it.

definition_en: To leave a place OR become known.

examples.sentence: We need to get out of this contract.
The secret got out.
Get out of the building immediately!
Getting the product out on time was hard.

definition_en: To recover from something OR communicate.

examples.sentence: We need to get over this setback.
She eventually got over her disappointment.
I can't get over how successful it was.
Getting over the language barrier takes time.

definition_en: To finish a task OR connect by phone.

examples.sentence: I finally got through to customer support.
We have a lot of data to get through.
She got through the interview successfully.
How can we get through to them?

definition_en: To meet socially or for work.

examples.sentence: Let's get together for a brainstorming session.
They got together to sign the deal.
We should get together more often.
Getting everyone together is difficult.

definition_en: To rise from bed OR organize.

examples.sentence: I get up early to check emails.
She got up to leave the meeting.
We need to get up a petition.
Get up to speed.

definition_en: To give for free OR reveal a secret.

examples.sentence: They are giving away free samples.
Don't give away our strategy.
His face gave nothing away.
A giveaway.

definition_en: To return something.

examples.sentence: It's time to give back to the community.
Please give back the signed copy.
He gave back the award.
Giving back creates goodwill.

definition_en: To quit or stop doing something.

examples.sentence: Don't give up on the project yet.
He gave up smoking last year.
They gave up the search.
Giving up is not an option.

definition_en: To pursue something.

examples.sentence: We decided to go after the youth market.
She went after the promotion aggressively.
Go after your goals.
Are they going after our clients?

definition_en: To return to a place or topic.

examples.sentence: Let's go back to the previous slide.
We can't go back now.
This policy goes back to the founder.
Going back on your word destroys trust.

definition_en: To explode/ring OR turn bad (food).

examples.sentence: The fire alarm went off at noon.
My presentation went off well.
The milk has gone off.
Did the meeting go off as planned?

definition_en: To continue or happen.

examples.sentence: Please go on with your report.
What is going on here?
The meeting went on for too long.
Life goes on.

definition_en: To leave work/home OR stop burning.

examples.sentence: The lights went out during the storm.
Do you go out much with colleagues?
This newsletter goes out to all staff.
Going out for business lunches is common.

definition_en: To become an adult or mature.

examples.sentence: The market is growing up.
It's time for the startup to grow up.
He grew up in France.
A grown-up approach to business.

definition_en: To wait.

examples.sentence: Hang on a second, please.
Can you hang on while I check?
Everything hangs on this decision.
Hanging on for too long is risky.

definition_en: To end a phone call.

examples.sentence: Don't hang up yet!
He hung up on me angrily.
After hanging up, I sent an email.
The call ended when she hung up.

definition_en: To wait.

examples.sentence: Please hold on while I transfer you.
Hold on, I don't agree.
We managed to hold on to our market share.
Just hold on a minute.

definition_en: To do something quickly.

examples.sentence: We need to hurry up to meet the deadline.
Hurry up, the meeting is starting!
He urged us to hurry up.
Why the hurry?

definition_en: To participate.

examples.sentence: Please join in the discussion.
Everyone joined in to help.
Feel free to join in anytime.
Joining in shows commitment.

definition_en: To continue doing something.

examples.sentence: We must keep on trying.
He kept on talking during the presentation.
If you keep on like this, you'll succeed.
The costs keep on rising.

definition_en: To stop someone entering.

examples.sentence: Unauthorized personnel must keep out.
We need to keep competitors out of this market.
Keep out of the discussion if you don't have facts.
The login system keeps hackers out.

definition_en: To disappoint someone.

examples.sentence: I won't let you down.
The supplier let us down again.
He felt let down by the company.
Letting down a client is serious.

definition_en: To allow someone to enter.

examples.sentence: Please let the visitors in.
The security guard let me in.
Don't let anyone in without a badge.
This gap lets in draft.

definition_en: To access a computer system.

examples.sentence: Please log in with your credentials.
I can't log in to the network.
He logged in remotely.
Logging in takes too long.

definition_en: To exit a computer system.

examples.sentence: Remember to log off before you leave.
The system logs off automatically.
She logged off at 5 PM.
Why did you log off?

definition_en: To take care of someone/something.

examples.sentence: Who looks after the interns?
I'll look after the arrangements.
Looking after clients is key.
She looked after the project while he was away.

definition_en: To think about the past.

examples.sentence: Looking back, it was a good decision.
Don't look back in anger.
We looked back on our first year.
Never look back.

definition_en: To search for something.

examples.sentence: We are looking for a new manager.
What are you looking for?
I looked for the file everywhere.
Start looking for alternatives.

definition_en: To anticipate with pleasure.
translation_pl: oczekiwać z niecierpliwością, cieszyć się na

examples.sentence: I look forward to meeting you.
We look forward to your reply.
She is looking forward to the holiday.
He looked forward to retirement.

definition_en: To search for information OR improve.

examples.sentence: I need to look up this word.
Can you look up the client's details?
Things are looking up.
Look it up online.

definition_en: To respect and admire someone.

examples.sentence: I look up to my mentor.
Employees look up to a strong leader.
She is someone to look up to.
He always looked up to his father.

definition_en: To invent OR constitute OR compensate.

examples.sentence: He made up an excuse.
Women make up 50% of the workforce.
We need to make up the difference.
I'll make it up to you.

definition_en: To confuse two things.

examples.sentence: I mixed up the dates.
Don't mix up the files.
He always mixes me up with my brother.
Sorry, it was a mix-up.

definition_en: To proceed to the next topic or stage.

examples.sentence: Let's move on to the next item.
It's time to move on.
He moved on to a new company.
Moving on...

definition_en: To repay money.

examples.sentence: We must pay back the loan.
The investment pays back in 3 years.
When can you pay me back?
Payback time.

definition_en: To produce a hard copy.

examples.sentence: Can you print out the agenda?
I printed out two copies.
Don't print it out unless necessary.
Printing out emails is wasteful.

definition_en: To assemble or organize.

examples.sentence: Let's put together a plan.
She put together a great team.
It took hours to put it together.
Putting together this report was hard.

definition_en: To tolerate.

examples.sentence: I can't put up with this noise.
She put up with a difficult boss.
Why do you put up with it?
Putting up with delays is frustrating.

definition_en: To escape.

examples.sentence: Don't run away from problems.
The thief ran away.
He wants to run away and join a circus.
Running away won't help.

definition_en: To say goodbye to someone leaving.

examples.sentence: I went to the airport to see him off.
The team saw off the visitors.
Let's see them off.
Seeing off a colleague is polite.

definition_en: To start a journey.

examples.sentence: We set off at dawn.
What time should we set off?
Setting off early avoids traffic.
They set off for Paris.

definition_en: To arrive or appear.

examples.sentence: He didn't show up for the meeting.
She finally showed up.
Don't just show up uninvited.
Showing up late is rude.

definition_en: To turn off a machine or close business.

examples.sentence: Shut down your computer.
The factory shut down last year.
We are shutting down the server for maintenance.
Automatic shutdown.

definition_en: To register.

examples.sentence: Sign up for the newsletter.
Have you signed up yet?
I signed up for the course.
Signing up is free.

definition_en: To reduce speed.

examples.sentence: Growth is slowing down.
You need to slow down and rest.
Slow down, you're driving too fast.
A slowdown in sales.

definition_en: To increase speed.

examples.sentence: We need to speed up the process.
Can you speed it up?
Production sped up recently.
Speeding up delivery costs extra.

definition_en: To be noticeable or better than others.

examples.sentence: Your resume stood out.
We need a brand that stands out.
He stands out in a crowd.
Make your application stand out.

definition_en: To turn off OR stop paying attention/relax.

examples.sentence: Switch off the lights.
It's hard to switch off after work.
I just switched off and watched TV.
He switched off during the lecture.

definition_en: To activate something.

examples.sentence: Switch on the projector.
The alarm switches on automatically.
Can you switch on the air con?
He switched on his charm.

definition_en: To retract statement OR return item.

examples.sentence: I take back what I said.
Can I take this shirt back?
They agreed to take back the faulty goods.
Taking back a promise breaks trust.

definition_en: To become successful OR plane departure.

examples.sentence: Her career really took off.
The plane takes off at 9.
Sales are taking off.
Before takeoff, fasten seatbelts.

definition_en: To start a hobby OR occupy space/time.

examples.sentence: I took up golf for networking.
This project takes up all my time.
Do not take up too much space.
Taking up a new language is hard.

definition_en: To discard.

examples.sentence: Don't throw away these files.
He threw away a great opportunity.
We are a throwaway society.
Throwing away food is bad.

definition_en: To test something.

examples.sentence: We are trying out a new strategy.
Can I try out the software first?
They tried out several candidates.
A tryout session.

definition_en: To change direction OR improve a business.

examples.sentence: The new CEO turned the company around.
We need a quick turnaround.
Turn around and look at the chart.
Turning around a failing business is tough.

definition_en: To happen in the end/result.

examples.sentence: It turned out to be a mistake.
The event turned out well.
How did the vote turn out?
A good turnout.

definition_en: To arrive/appear unexpectedly OR increase volume.

examples.sentence: He turned up late as usual.
Something better will turn up.
Turn up the volume.
Don't expect clients to just turn up.

definition_en: To consume completely.

examples.sentence: We used up the budget.
Don't use up all the paper.
He used up his sick leave.
Using up resources responsibly.

definition_en: To stop sleeping OR realize reality.

examples.sentence: We need to wake up to the threat.
It was a wake-up call.
I woke up early.
Wake up and smell the coffee.

definition_en: To be careful.

examples.sentence: Watch out for scams.
You need to watch out.
Watch out! A car is coming.
Watching out for risks is part of my job.

definition_en: To become unusable via use OR exhaust someone.

examples.sentence: The machine helps worn out parts.
This detailed work wears me out.
I'm completely worn out.
Don't wear yourself out.

definition_en: To solve/calculate OR exercise.

examples.sentence: We worked out a compromise.
I work out three times a week.
Things didn't work out as planned.
Can you work out the cost?

definition_en: To record in writing.

examples.sentence: Write down these instructions.
I wrote it down somewhere.
Did you write down the address?
A write-down of assets.

definition_en: To focus on details/magnify.

examples.sentence: Zoom in on this chart.
Let's zoom in on the specifics.
The camera zoomed in.
Zooming in helps identify errors.

definition_en: To view the bigger picture.

examples.sentence: We need to zoom out and look at the strategy.
Zoom out to see the whole map.
Zooming out gives perspective.
If you zoom out, the trend is clear.

definition_en: To interrupt OR enter illegally OR train/test.
translation_pl: wtrącić się, włamać się, dotrzeć (np. buty/silnik)

examples.sentence: Sorry to break in, but I have news.
Thieves broke in last night.
We are breaking in the new interns.
I need to break in these shoes.

definition_en: To refresh one's knowledge.

examples.sentence: I need to brush up on my Spanish.
Brush up on your excel skills.
He brushed up on the regulations.
Brushing up is always useful.

definition_en: To visit OR acquire.

examples.sentence: Jobs are hard to come by.
Please come by my office.
How did you come by this info?
He came by some money unexpectedly.

definition_en: To quit (school/race).

examples.sentence: He dropped out of college.
The candidate dropped out of the race.
Don't drop out now.
A high dropout rate.

definition_en: To restrain or keep secret.

examples.sentence: Don't hold back your ideas.
He held back his anger.
They are holding back information.
Something is holding back growth.

definition_en: To emit (smell/heat/vibes).

examples.sentence: The machine gives off heat.
He gives off a confident vibe.
This plant gives off a bad smell.
Giving off mixed signals.

definition_en: To become liked gradually.

examples.sentence: This idea is growing on me.
The new office will grow on you.
He eventually grew on the team.
Acquired tastes grow on you.

definition_en: To distribute.

examples.sentence: Please hand out the brochures.
They handed out prizes.
Handing out tasks effectively is a skill.
Hand-out materials.
